hints_html: The linear approximation method requires choosing a value that is easy to calculate (usually denoted by the variable a), near the value being approximated. What would be a good choice for this question?

hints_raw: The linear approximation method requires choosing a value that is easy to calculate (usually denoted by the variable ''a''), near the value being approximated.  What would be a good choice for this question?
question: 9 (a)
sols_html:
The linear approximation formula is

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) \approx L(x) = f'(a)(x-a) + f(a)\end{aligned}\]

For some value a that is near the value to be approximated. In our case, \(f(x) = e^x\) and a sensible choice for a would be 0 as it is easy to calculate \(\displaystyle f(0) = e^0\) and \(\displaystyle f'(0) = e^0\). Plugging this into our formula for L(x) we have:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle L(x) = e^0(x - 0) + e^0\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle L(x) = x + 1\end{aligned}\]

To approximate \(e^{0.1}\), we simply plug in \(x = 0.1\) to get

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle L(0.1) = 0.1 + 1 = 1.1\end{aligned}\]
